1.28.text:
you always watch unfold 
the Fundamental Problem of Traffic.

4.70.text: On green, the first car accelerates, and then the next,

7.68.text: and then the next, and then the next, and then you,

14.54.text: you would have made it through.

16.38.text: Coordination - not cars - is the problem,

19.32.text:
because we are
monkey drivers with slow reaction times

24.18.text:
Even if we tried getting everyone to
press the pedal on 3-2-1-now

30.68.text:
This dis-coordination limits
how many cars can get through an intersection

34.04.text: and when one backs up to the next,

36.20.text:
that's when city-sized gridlock cascades
happen, taking forever to clear.

40.70.text:
In general, more intersections equals more 
dis-coordination which equals more traffic.

44.54.text:
This is the motive behind big highways:
no intersections.

47.58.text: Splits and merges, yes. Intersections, no.

50.46.text: No stopping, no coordination problems, no traffic

54.64.text:
Intersections outside of a highway
 will back up onto it.

57.18.text:
Again, because human reaction times
 limit how many cars can escape the off-ramp

62.27.text:
But, even without intersections,
there would still be traffic on the highway.

68.24.text: Take a one lane highway with happy cars flowing

70.52.text: until a chicken crosses the road.

72.44.text: The driver who sees it brakes a little,

73.86.text:
the driver behind him doesn't notice immediately
and brakes a little harder than necessary,

77.38.text:
the driver behind him does the same 
until someone comes to a complete stop

81.22.text:
and, oh look, cars approaching at highway
speeds must now stop as well.

85.36.text:
Though the chicken is long gone,
it left a phantom intersection on the highway.

90.06.text:
This is what's happened when
you're stuck in traffic for hours thinking,

92.74.text:
"There must be a deadly pile up ahead"
and then suddenly, the traffic's over

96.12.text:
with no wreckage in sight, 
to your relief if you're a good person

99.06.text: and mild annoyance if you aren't.

100.68.text:
You just pass through a
phantom intersection,

102.86.text: the cause of which is long gone.

107.14.text: It's really a traffic snake slithering down the road

110.08.text:
eating oncoming cars at one end
and pooping them out the other.

113.52.text: On a ring road, a single car slowing down

115.74.text: will start an Ouroboros of traffic that will last forever,

118.56.text: even though there's no problem with the road.

121.34.text:
If the drivers could coordinate to
accelerate and separate simultaneously,

126.86.text: But they can't, so traffic eternal.

129.16.text:
On highways, traffic snakes grow
if cars are eaten faster than excreted,

133.04.text: and they shrink if excreted faster than eaten,

135.36.text:
dying when the last car accelerates away
 before the next car must stop.

139.50.text:
Now, in multi-lane highways,
 there needs be no chicken to start gridlock.

142.82.text:
A driver crossing lanes quickly
with cars too close behind is enough

146.76.text:
to birth a traffic snake that lives for
hours and leagues.

149.72.text:
It's this quick crossing that causes
drivers behind to over-brake and begin a chain reaction.

154.92.text:
But we *can* make traffic
snakes less likely by changing the way we drive.

159.62.text:
Your goal as a driver is to
stay the same distance from the car ahead

162.82.text: as from the car behind at all times.

165.42.text:
Tailgating is trouble. Not just because
it makes accidents more likely but

168.51.text:
because you as the tailgater can start a
traffic snake if the driver ahead brakes.

174.99.text:
This gives you the most time
to prevent over-braking

177.21.text:
but also gives the driver
behind you the most time as well.

181.65.text: this rule would get all cars to pull apart the snake faster.

186.30.text:
That's the simple solution to traffic:
getting humans to change their behavior,

190.44.text:
perhaps by sharing this video to show
how and why traffic happens,

193.86.text: why tailgaters are trouble, and how we can work together to make the roads better for all.

201.57.text:
wishing upon a star that people are
better than they are is a terrible solution.

206.58.text:
Instead, what works is a
structurally systematized solution

209.79.text: which is exactly what self-driving cars are.

212.45.text: Self-driving cars can just be programmed

214.07.text: to stay in the middle and accelerate simultaneously.

217.50.text:
The more self-driving cars at an intersection,
the more efficient the intersection gets.

221.34.text:
A solid lane of self-driving cars
vastly increases throughput.

226.73.text:
If you ban humans from the road
(which we should totally do anyway)

229.98.text: you can get rid of the intersection entirely.

232.30.text:
After all, a traffic light is just a tool for drivers
on one road to communicate with drivers

239.58.text:
Red equals "Don't go now,
we are coming through the intersection."

243.64.text:
But self-driving cars can talk
to each other at the speed of light.

247.40.text: with that kind of coordination, no traffic light necessary.

250.23.text:
Just as with the highway, the best
intersection is no intersection.

254.67.text: Humans will never drive this precisely.

256.99.text: At the intersection, the fundamental problem with traffic

259.88.text: that you watch unfold, as well as everything, is people.

263.26.text: So the real simple solution to traffic:

265.34.text: is no more monkeys driving cars.
